cab.content: SECRET31WAR CABINET, 131.Minutes of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10, Downing Street, S.W., onThursday, May 3, 1917, at 1T30 a.m.Present:The Right Hon. A. Bonar. Law, M.P. Dally Jones, Acting Secretary.Captain Clement Jones, Assistant Secretary.Fleet Paymaster P. H. Row, R.N., Assistant Secretary.salonica.1. COLONEL BARTHOLOMEW, acting for the Director ofMilitary Operations, reported that General Sarrail had deferred hisattack for a few days on account of bad weather.The Western 2. Colonel Bartholomew gave the War Cabinet particularsFront. which had been received in regard to the date and place of theproposed action on a small portion of the French front.German Reserves.3. Colonel Bartholomew reported that the German reserves onthe Western front amounted to forty divisions (of which eleven werefresh and twenty-nine tired), as compared with forty-nine reserve divisions at the beginning of April before our offensive.British Casualties.4. The Secretary of State for War reported that the Britishcasualties on the Western front since the beginning of the attackamounted to a total of 86,000 rank and file. After some discussion as to the advisability of publishing the numbers of our casualties, theWar Cabinet decided that -The figures for these casualties should be announced at theforthcoming Secret Session in the House of Commons,;, together with a comparative statement of our casualties during the operations on the Somme in 1916.7'printed for the War Cabinet. May 191.7. Submarines.5. The Chief of the War Staff reported various engagements with enemy submarines, and stated that " E 54 " had arrived atQueenstown with a portion of the German crew of "U 81," one of '-*)the newest type of submarines, which she had sunk. ^Parcels for Troopsin Prance.6. The War Cabinet had under consideration a memorandumby the Secretary of State for War (Paper G.T.-581) in regard to the sending by individuals of foodstuffs to troops in France. ' Theseparcels were found to contain a total of about 10,000 tons of bread-stuffs a month, additional to the ordinary issue.The War Cabinet were of opinion that it would be inadvisable to stop these parcels, having regard to the large amount of heart-burning there would be on the subject,with a view to economy to foodstuffs, that-They decided, however,The sale of breadstuffs should be prohibited in all canteens inthe line of communication areas, except at railway stations,and authorised the Secretary of State for War to issue thenecessary instructions to that effect.Supplies of Foodsent to british prisoners of Warin Germany and elsewhere.7. With reference to Paper G.T.-558 on this subject, theSecretary of State for War said that he would like to bring officers'parcels under supervision in the same way as the men's. Theamount of parcels that can be sent to an officer is at presentunlimited, and, as an instance, an extreme case was mentioned ofone officer who receives 178 lb. of food every fortnight. lord derby said the question was one of principle, and he was in favournot only of limiting the amount to be sent to officers to a definiteweight, but also of selecting certain places for packing the parcels,in order to relieve the strain on the censoFs office.The War Cabinet decided that The Secretary of State for War should submit definite proposals on the subject to the Army Council and then report to theWar Cabinet.Punishment forWomen in Prance.8. The Secretary of State for War reported to the War Cabinetthat objections were being raised by the Labour Minister and theSecretary for Scotland with regard to the scale of disciplinary actionin the cases of women sent to France by the War Office. He statedthat enlistment for this service was entirely voluntary, and that theterms of punishment were clearly put before the women in theagreement which they signed. He had arranged to confer with theSecretary for Scotland on the subject.Reconstruction ofWar TradeAdvisoryCommittee.9. With reference to Paper G.T.-516 on this subject, the WarCabinet decided that The question of the Reconstruction of the War Trade AdvisoryCommittee should he settled by a Committee composedof :-Lord Robert Cecil (in the Chair),Lord Emmott,Sir Francis Hopwood, andMr. E S. Montagu,who should- report to the War Cabinet their decision. a :159General SarraiL10. The War Cabinet had before them telegram No. 972, datedthe 2nd May, 1917, from Athens, in regard to General SarraiTsrefusal to allow 100 Greek seamen to remain in Athens and 150 inPiraaus for various services, including employment at the Ministryof Marine.The War Cabinet instructed the Acting Secretary to transmitthis telegram to the Prime Minister in France.(Initialled)A.
